Rationale
Change BoS to LS Curriculum Board
Blurb
Overview
This module will build on previous skills modules, developing skills in critical thinking, data interpretation and analysis, scientific writing, communication, research skills and teamwork. The module consists of lectures, workshops and tutorials.

Students will be given three summative assessments over the course of the module. 1) A piece of science communication writing such as a POSTnote. 2) A critical review of a piece of research in bioveterinary sciences. 3) A data analysis poster presentation.
Educational Aims
This module aims to develop transferable skills in critical thinking, interpretation of data and science communication in the context of bioveterinary science.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module aims to provide a set of communication and critical reflection skills in the context of bioveterinary sciences. These skills will help students enhance the execution and presentation of their research project, prepare them for Level 6 assessments and maximise their employment and personal development opportunities. The module is taught though seminars and tutorials, but has a strong emphasis on independent learning. Learning material is provided through VITAL. The module is assessed by continuous assessment.
Outline Syllabus
Critical Thinking

Students on this module will be introduced to the key principles of critical thinking and will apply their skills to perform critical analyses of the scientific literature and produce a peer review for an article in the area of bioveterinary sciences.

Science Communication

The public perception of science is of increasing concern to scientists, policymakers, and educators. Students will learn about the modern challenges in science communication and the importance of good science communication in the area of bioveterinary sciences. These skills will be put into practice in different media including a written piece and a conference poster.

Research Skills

Students will develop their quantitative and research skills from previous modules and apply them to analyse real-world data in the area of bioveterinary sciences and present their results in a research conference style poster.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Synchronous and asynchronous online lectures, seminars, workshops and journal clubs; supported by face-to-face group sessions on campus Liverpool.

Sessions to support the critique / peer review will be held via a combination of online synchronous seminars and in-person face-to-face journal club discussion small group teaching on campus. Sessions to support the postnote assessment will be held via a combination of online synchronous seminars and in-person face-to-face discussion in small groups.

The critical review assessment will be supported by a series of online introductory lectures and 4 face-to-face mid-sized group sessions facilitated by an academic. Ahead of these sessions, students will be assigned reading which will form the basis of the discussion. The group will work to produce a collaboratively written document which will then serve as support material for the final assessment. Each session is connected to a research paper/area (selected by the academic) thus making the sessions "research-connected" (Liverpool Curriculum Framework) as well as giving the students an authentic experience (Liverpool Curriculum Framework) to actively train their critical analysis skills on cutting edge research (LO1, LO2, S1, S2, S4).

The scientific communication assessment will be supported by online workshops to aid the students in developing their writing skills as well as giving them an understanding of the wider significance of good science communication. The aim of these sessions is to give the students confidence (Liverpool Curriculum Framework) in their ability to communicate scientific complexities to non-specialist audiences and an understanding of how good science communication is an important aspect of global citizenship. There will be a session set aside for students to receive face-to-face formative feedback to assist in this assignment (LO3, LO4, S1, S4).

The learning outcome LO1 to analyse real-world data and S1 Scientific Communication and S3 Digital fluency, will be supported by online workshops in programme-specific data visualisation and data analysis workshops. These workshops are intended to give students the digital fluency required to perform and present research findings. (Liverpool Curriculum Framework)

“Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.”
Assessment Strategy
Assessment on this module is split into 2 parts. Each part aims to meet the Liverpool Curriculum Framework requirement of authenticity as described below.

1) Critical Review. Students will be assessed on their ability to critically evaluate scientific literature by producing a peer review critique of a scientific paper.

2) POSTnote. Based on major themes in current Bioveterinary research, students will produce a piece of scientific writing for non-specialist audiences (Members of Parliament).
Admin
Marked for Rollover
No
Replace Future Instances
No
Notes
This module is due to commence in September 2020

Rationale

Across the various programmes within Life Sciences, there is significant diversity amongst the third year advanced skills modules in terms of both student and staff workload. Because of this, programme directors and module leaders were brought together for a series of meetings to discuss a solution. Student feedback and performance on the existing modules was taken into account and the various components of each module were evaluated.

Following this review of the school's provision, it was decided that several programmes should be brought together onto similar module structures. This module is one of seven modules being brought onto this structure.

The previous 341 module contained 3 assessments (postnote, critical review and poster). ). The new proposed structure will have 2 coursework assessments taught through a hybrid learning platform in response to the COVID-19 pandemic and in line with school policy. The proposed summative assessments consist of two written pieces (Critical review and Postnote, 40% and 60% each respectively). Changes have been made in the way these assessments are supported (see syllabus) in response to student feedback and staff consultation and school advice on hybrid approach to active learning.

Advice on the best teaching methods to employ to deliver the content in support of each assessment was sought from CIE updates on Hybrid teaching modalities.

Rationale
Change BoS to LS Curriculum Board
Blurb
Overview
This module will build on previous skills modules, developing skills in critical thinking, data interpretation and analysis, scientific writing, communication, research skills and teamwork. The module consists of lectures, workshops and tutorials.

Students will be given three summative assessments over the course of the module. 1) A piece of science communication writing such as a POSTnote. 2) A critical review of a piece of research in bioveterinary sciences. 3) A data analysis poster presentation.
Educational Aims
This module aims to develop transferable skills in critical thinking, interpretation of data and science communication in the context of bioveterinary science.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module aims to provide a set of communication and critical reflection skills in the context of bioveterinary sciences. These skills will help students enhance the execution and presentation of their research project, prepare them for Level 6 assessments and maximise their employment and personal development opportunities. The module is taught though seminars and tutorials, but has a strong emphasis on independent learning. Learning material is provided through VITAL. The module is assessed by continuous assessment.
Outline Syllabus
Critical Thinking

Students on this module will be introduced to the key principles of critical thinking and will apply their skills to perform critical analyses of the scientific literature and produce a peer review for an article in the area of bioveterinary sciences.

Science Communication

The public perception of science is of increasing concern to scientists, policymakers, and educators. Students will learn about the modern challenges in science communication and the importance of good science communication in the area of bioveterinary sciences. These skills will be put into practice in different media including a written piece and a conference poster.

Research Skills

Students will develop their quantitative and research skills from previous modules and apply them to analyse real-world data in the area of bioveterinary sciences and present their results in a research conference style poster.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Synchronous and asynchronous online lectures, seminars, workshops and journal clubs; supported by face-to-face group sessions on campus Liverpool.

Sessions to support the critique / peer review will be held via a combination of online synchronous seminars and in-person face-to-face journal club discussion small group teaching on campus. Sessions to support the postnote assessment will be held via a combination of online synchronous seminars and in-person face-to-face discussion in small groups.

The critical review assessment will be supported by a series of online introductory lectures and 4 face-to-face mid-sized group sessions facilitated by an academic. Ahead of these sessions, students will be assigned reading which will form the basis of the discussion. The group will work to produce a collaboratively written document which will then serve as support material for the final assessment. Each session is connected to a research paper/area (selected by the academic) thus making the sessions "research-connected" (Liverpool Curriculum Framework) as well as giving the students an authentic experience (Liverpool Curriculum Framework) to actively train their critical analysis skills on cutting edge research (LO1, LO2, S1, S2, S4).

The scientific communication assessment will be supported by online workshops to aid the students in developing their writing skills as well as giving them an understanding of the wider significance of good science communication. The aim of these sessions is to give the students confidence (Liverpool Curriculum Framework) in their ability to communicate scientific complexities to non-specialist audiences and an understanding of how good science communication is an important aspect of global citizenship. There will be a session set aside for students to receive face-to-face formative feedback to assist in this assignment (LO3, LO4, S1, S4).

The learning outcome LO1 to analyse real-world data and S1 Scientific Communication and S3 Digital fluency, will be supported by online workshops in programme-specific data visualisation and data analysis workshops. These workshops are intended to give students the digital fluency required to perform and present research findings. (Liverpool Curriculum Framework)

“Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.”
Assessment Strategy
Assessment on this module is split into 2 parts. Each part aims to meet the Liverpool Curriculum Framework requirement of authenticity as described below.

1) Critical Review. Students will be assessed on their ability to critically evaluate scientific literature by producing a peer review critique of a scientific paper.

2) POSTnote. Based on major themes in current Bioveterinary research, students will produce a piece of scientific writing for non-specialist audiences (Members of Parliament).
Admin
Marked for Rollover
No
Replace Future Instances
No
Notes
This module is due to commence in September 2020

Rationale

Across the various programmes within Life Sciences, there is significant diversity amongst the third year advanced skills modules in terms of both student and staff workload. Because of this, programme directors and module leaders were brought together for a series of meetings to discuss a solution. Student feedback and performance on the existing modules was taken into account and the various components of each module were evaluated.

Following this review of the school's provision, it was decided that several programmes should be brought together onto similar module structures. This module is one of seven modules being brought onto this structure.

The previous 341 module contained 3 assessments (postnote, critical review and poster). ). The new proposed structure will have 2 coursework assessments taught through a hybrid learning platform in response to the COVID-19 pandemic and in line with school policy. The proposed summative assessments consist of two written pieces (Critical review and Postnote, 40% and 60% each respectively). Changes have been made in the way these assessments are supported (see syllabus) in response to student feedback and staff consultation and school advice on hybrid approach to active learning.

Advice on the best teaching methods to employ to deliver the content in support of each assessment was sought from CIE updates on Hybrid teaching modalities.
